prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: There are numerous other statutes which may require businesses to provide information to the government. One of the most common events triggering such an obligation is the negotiation of a corporate transaction. In that regard, companies must consider the disclosure obligations under the relevant securities legislation,[1] the Competition Act[2] and the Investment Canada Act.[3] Other statutes such as environmental[4] and occupational health and safety legislation,[5] require disclosure on an ongoing basis.
See, for example, the Ontario Securities Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. S.5.
See, for example, the Ontario Environmental Protection Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. E.19.
See, for example, the Ontario Occupational Health and Safety Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. O.1.
